results.title: Lonely Hearts
results.creator_credit: John B Murray, Adams Packer Films and Paul Cox
results.brief_description: There’s nothing the matter with sexual inexperience. It’s perfectly natural as Peter and Patricia eventually discover after some rather embarrassing and sensitive moments. Having met through a lonely hearts club, they embark on a timid, tentative relationship, but problems arise because of Peter’s clumsy attempts at love making. What follows is a delightful, sensitive love story, simply told with compassion and humour, full of real characters who surround and complicate our everyday lives. Starring Wendy Hughes and Norman Kaye.

results.title: Lonely boy
results.brief_description: The story of popular singer Paul Anka. From obscurity in Ottawa he became the idol of millions of adolescent fans around the world. This film takes a candid look from both sides of the footlights.

results.title: Lone star
results.creator_credit: Castle Rock Entertainment, R. Miller, Maggie Renzi and John Sayles
results.brief_description: The shocking discovery of a human skull in the Texas desert starts Sheriff Sam Deeds on the trail to solve a forty-year-old mystery. Deed’s investigation implicates many in the town, both alive and dead… but most surprisingly of all, his own father, who was a legendary lawman and prominent figure in the town’s history. A typically acute, intricate and intelligent film from the most ambitious of US film directors it takes the broad canvas of a Texan border town community to explore how the past constantly impinges on the present, however much we try to fence it off.

results.title: Lone ranger
results.brief_description: An example of student film making; a zany view of one man’s day in London with homage to as many movie moguls as one can recognise from Frankenstein to Jean-Luc-Godard, with the Marx Brothers and Richard Lester thrown in - highly accomplished and very amusing. Music by Pete Townsend.

results.title: London Underground Map
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Designed by Harry Beck in 1933, this diagrammatic map hangs on the walls of London’s 273 Underground train stations and in the Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art in New York. A masterpiece of graphic design, it has become a symbol of London all over the world.

results.title: London to Brighton in four minutes
results.brief_description: By use of timelapse photography, this film gives an impression of travel by train at approximately the speed of sound. Photographed at two frames per second (instead of the normal twenty four) from the train driver’s cabin, every foot of the rail track is seen. Whereas the journey from London to Brighton takes an hour at an average speed of 65 miles per hour, this unusual journey takes four minutes at an average speed of 800 miles per hour.

results.title: London terminus
results.brief_description: From London a vast national railway system radiates: at the railway terminus in London, 1,704 trains enter and leave the station every day. Millions of urban workers depend entirely on the railway system for their daily transport to and from central London, and, in addition, there are many expresses and goods trains which span the length and breadth of Great Britain. Music composed by Horace Somerville, played by London Symphony Orchestra under Muir Mathieson.

results.title: London scene
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: A picture of life in London. Follows the course of a typical day: arrival of early-morning fruit and vegetables at Covent Garden; invasion of the City by a million workers from the suburbs; the parks of London, havens for office workers during lungh-time; diversity of shops and busy streets; the zoo; Crown Jewels in the Tower. After dark, the cry of “Time, gentlemen, please!” in the public hotels brings the day to a close.
